fields.description:
When a Review is created, review content is added, click Done and an error is generated (see below)

Windows XP, with FireFox 4. The browser does not crash, and the review is successfully created. This has happened a few times, but is not consistent.

Error 2
[Exception... fields.summary: LazyInitializationException when accessing a code review

fields.description:
GUI crashes when working with files larger than 10000 LOC

Comment was made on file larger than 10000 lines, when trying to open the file in the review browser crashes.

Probably this error is connected with similar problem in FishEye (FE-3464),
but when FishEye simply doesn't show the rest of the file Crucible review
crashes browser - in Firefox I got message:

[Exception... "Component returned failure code: 0x8007000e (NS_ERROR_OUT_OF_MEMORY) [nsIXMLHttpRequest.responseText]" nsresult: "0x8007000e (NS_ERROR_OUT_OF_MEMORY)" location: "JS frame ::
fields.summary: GUI crashes when working with files larger than 10000 LOC
After migrating to MS SQL Server 2008, FeCru is unable to parse config.xml

fields.description:
On atlaseye navigate to a repository and in the file view click on the trunk folder and the tabs above the content-view section disappear. (See attachments).
This also exists in Studio which is using FE 2.5 and happens in IE7 as well as IE8.
fields.summary: Selecting a folder in File browser in FE on IE8 causes content-view tabs to disappear

fields.description:
In this case the link to BEAC seems to cause a failure 

!https://img.skitch.com/20110601-mrebjnu92mjf8shs2i3b1cfm9y.png!
fields.summary: Applinks to non-JIRA servers confuse the Crucible link review to issue process

fields.description:
Even though resolving JIRA issues is optional, if the process throws an exception the entire request fails. We need to catch all exceptions and simply act as though the issue was not found.

{noformat}
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.JiraIssueImpl.copyFieldsFrom(JiraIssueImpl.java:92)
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.JiraIssueImpl.<init>(JiraIssueImpl.java:75)
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.JiraServerImpl.getIssue(JiraServerImpl.java:249)
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.issue.JiraIssueServiceImpl.retrieveJiraIssue(JiraIssueServiceImpl.java:277)
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.issue.JiraIssueServiceImpl.getJiraIssue(JiraIssueServiceImpl.java:183)
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.AjaxJiraIssueHelper.tryGetJiraIssue(AjaxJiraIssueHelper.java:48)
	at com.atlassian.fisheye.jira.AjaxJiraIssueHelper.tryGetJiraIssue(AjaxJiraIssueHelper.java:40)
{noformat}
fields.summary: Exception while looking up JIRA issue ends request in error

fields.description:
Create a review with a single attachment and a general comment.

Click the 'Go to next element' button while on the general comment, and your browser will hang.

The culprit is the while loop in {{getPredictedFrxsToLoad}}.
fields.summary: In a Review containing a single Attachment, the 'Go to next element' button causes an infinite Javascript loop

fields.description:
If an error occurs in {{JiraServerImpl.getIssue}} the exception is not caught and logged as it should be, but causes the request to fail.

Failure to link to a JIRA issue should be non-fatal.
fields.summary: NPE when trying to link review to JIRA issue causes failure of review creation

fields.description:
Steps for Replication:

1. Create a review. 
2. Abandon it.
3. Search for this abandoned review via the custom filter by checking the "Abandoned" checkbox. The review is listed correctly.
4. Re-index Crucible data via {{Administration ->Crucible}}.
5. Revisit the custom filter and notice the abandoned review is no longer in the resultant list.
6. The review is still accessible using the URL:
{noformat}
http://<Fisheye_Base_URL>/cru/<Review Key>
{noformat}
fields.summary: Abandoned reviews cannot be searched for after a Crucible reindex

fields.description:
This occurs because of two defects:

1. If no allowed reviewers are specified in the destination project (i.e. there is no restriction) we assume that the current moderator is not allowed to moderate in the new project, and attempt to replace them with the default moderator from the noew project. In fact we should not change the moderator, as no restriction is in force in the new project.

2. When we change moderators we don't check to see if the old and the new moderators are the same user -- we remove the old and add the new regardless. For some reason Hibernate does not issue the SQL to remove the old moderator, and so the same user appears twice as a participant on the review, causing a constraint vialoation.
fields.summary: Moving a review between projects fails when the default moderator of the destination project is the same as the current moderator

fields.description:

- make the process faster

fields.description:
We have a lot of refactoring occurring in our project - constantly files are moving from package to package, project to project, as we see fit for organizing the code.

Though this makes for a better-looking codebase, it is a nightmare in Crucible - the files that are moved show as "file outdated" and if the latest changeset is added, it shows the entire file as deleted. This not ideal, because the file is not deleted, it has simply moved.  When this happens we must find the new file location and add it to the review; but even then that leaves us with 2 files and a broken "diff" from the original change in the original file location to the last change in the current/new file location.

What I would like to see is for Crucible to do one or both (and let the user choose on a file-by-file or project-by-project basis) of the following:

# Track the move/rename and allow the diff to encompass both the original file location and the new file location.
** I realize that not everyone might want Crucible to work this way (some people might want to see the new location of the file to ensure it is appropriately located) - however this is still a good option for a user to choose from to suit their needs.
# When the user chooses "Add Latest" to the review, and the file has been moved: prompt to add the file at its new location & mark the original as deleted, rather than exclusively updating the original file location to deleted (as it does today).
** This is also a good option - no one wants to just add the deleted file and leave it that way in the review when there has been subsequent changes made to the file after it has been moved.

*Example:*
File Meat.java was moved in Version Control from /src/path1 to /src/path2, and then some subsequent changes were made. In Crucible it shows the file at/src/path1/Meat.java as outdated.  If "Update to Latest" were chosen, Meat.java would then be marked as deleted in the review - not ideal as it is not deleted!

On a sidenote regarding this example:
If I go to the /src/path2/Meat.java in Fisheye, I can see all of the history (Good (y)). This type of a view is really what I want to see in Crucible, as it unites the original file location and the new file location to seamlessly cover the changes to the file in both the original and new location, and permits diffs between the file when it existed in its old location and its new location.


FYI - We are using Subversion, but this improvement should be VC-agnostic: it should work on any version control that tracks file moves.
fields.summary: Improve Crucible's Handling of Moved Files to Allow Free-Flowing diff Across File Locations

fields.description:
(This is the second time I've tried to enter this long description, as my first attempt went to a "Sorry Mate" page, and when I clicked Back, I found my long description was gone.  Very annoying.  I guess I'll first save the body to another editor before I submit next time.)

Our current Crucible/Fisheye evaluation and our production Fisheye instance are using HSQLDB.  We're finding that the performance of certain operations is very poor, and I need to understand what we can do, if anything, about this.

In our current production environment, most normal users don't use Fisheye, but I believe that when/if we integrate Crucible, that usage will increase.  If it does, and our performance doesn't improve, this will be a failure.

We know that the server our Crucible/Fisheye evaluation is running on is somewhat flow, but our production Fisheye instance is running on a faster box.

our SVN repo has about 11MLOC and 123k commits.

When we add a new SVN top-level module, that has required a reindexing, which takes 3 full WEEKS of clock time.  That will be a big problem if it's really that slow in production.

As I've concluded that the changeset search facilities in Crucible weren't very powerful, I've started to look at the changeset search facilities in Fisheye.  I tried a simple search for all changesets owned by me, and dated after March 1st.  That search returned in a reasonable length of time, perhaps 1-2 minutes.  I then tried adding a value in the "file name" field, because I wanted to see the changesets for a particular directory tree.  As it's supposedly an "Ant glob" field, I entered "**/apiservice/**", as I wanted to see all the changesets in that directory tree.  This search took essentially forever, as I've never waited long enough for it to complete.  I believe I've waited up to 10 minutes before giving up on this.

We'd like to convert to Oracle, but I'd like to be convinced that doing that will result in a significant improvement in our performance results.

I would attach the support zip, but it's a little over 18mb, which is over your limit.
fields.summary: Will our performance improve when/if we move from HSQLDB to Oracle?

fields.description:
In my organization, I believe that most of our reviews will be created from changesets. The functionality we have for browsing and searching changesets in Crucible seems to be lacking.

From what I can see, I can list the changesets that exactly match certain attribute values, like repository, branch, author, and "tag".

It appears that the list of changesets changes whenever any of these attribute fields change, so there's no way to change two of them and do the search. I would imagine a more typical search interface would have an action button that initiates the refresh.

We are going to want more sophisticated search capabilities. For instance, I'd like to see these search attributes:
 o A start and end date range (changesets created in that date range)
 o A regexp of an element name (changesets touching elements matching that regexp)
 o A regexp of a directory name (changesets on elements in directory trees matching that regexp)
fields.summary: Need better changeset search facilities

fields.description:
The session factory we create at start up is exposed as a spring bean and is injected into (e.g.) {{org.springframework.orm.hibernate3.HibernateTransactionManager}}. When we discard this session factory after migrating databases the original session factory is still used by these beans, causing (e.g.) the plugins pages to try to start a transaction using the old DB.

As a work around a restart after migration will ensure that the correct SessionFactory is used.
fields.summary: After migrating to a different database, session factories injected into spring beans still point to the old database.

fields.description:
The "Immediate" notification settings does not send out the notification immediately but "batches" all changes made in the past 'n' mins and sends out a single email.
The "Batch" option on the other hand, will send out a single notification including all changes made in the last 30mins.
It would help to clarify this difference, as "Immediate" might be a bit confusing, as it still sends out "batched" notifications.
We could also add a sample of each type to help make it more clear. 
This is with reference to this improvement request implemented in 2.5:
http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-137

The notifications have been documented [here|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Changing+your+User+Profile#ChangingyourUserProfile-ReviewsTab].
fields.summary: Improve Crucible notification documentation to clarify the "Immediate" option

fields.description:

I'm using FishEye 2.5.3 and Google Chrome.

fields.description:
When code inspections are done using a patch (so pre-commit) and later the code is commited, the changes set that was reviewed in the patch is not marked as inspected.

Here is a scenario.
1. Designer A makes changes in WC and creates a patch.
2. Designer A creates a Crucible code inspection using the patch.
3. Designer B inspects the code and says it's OK.
4. Designer A completes the code inspection.
5. Designer A committs the code to the trunk.
6. The committed changeset shows up in Crucible as not code inspected.

Is this expected behaviour? Are there plans to change this functionality? If not what is the reasoning behind it.

Thanks.

Tom
fields.summary: Pre-commit code inspections on patches do not mark corresponding committed changes set as inspected

The [Supported Platforms|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Supported+Platforms] page for Crucible does not have Oracle as a supported database.
Please update the page as per Fisheye's [Supported Platforms|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Supported+Platforms] document.
fields.summary: Update Crucible "Supported Platforms" page to add Oracle Support

fields.description:
For the query https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/rest-service/reviews-v1/filter?author=admin&states=Approval,Review,Summarize (assuming you've authenticated with atlaseye already), the result set returned includes all open reviews for all authors, not just those for 'admin'. This is because if the author isn't a user in crucible, the author part of the filter is ignored.

If you haven't authenticated, the result set (correctly?) returns 0 results.
fields.summary: REST review filter with unknown author matches everything instead

fields.description: When asking for reviews for a username that doesn't exist in the system, it just returns all reviews rather than no reviews.  Not only are they bizzare results, this can't be very performant.
fields.summary: Problem when using REST to retrieve all reviews for a non-existant user

fields.description:
Hello,

I'm using FishEye / Crucible 2.5.2 and Internet Explorer 8.
When I click on the Tools menu on the top right corner, the RSS Feed option is not displayed correctly.
It is covered by the table below.

This problem does not occur on Firefox.

Please see the screenshot attached.

Please let me know if you need further explanation.
fields.summary: RSS Feed option under Tools menu is not displaying correctly on IE8

fields.description:
Premise for Crucible:
Commit a file 3x, each time adding some lines of "code", generating three revisions on the repository: r1, r2 and r3.

In Crucible Reviews, if you:
# Click on "Create Review"
# Select "Search for Files"
# Select, for example, r1 and r3
# Click on "Start Review"
# Click on the file listed on the left hand side
# All three revisions are displayed.

According to our development team, this is the default behaviour of Crucible, because in the general sense, diffs are cumulative. For a sequence of three revisions r1, r2, and r3, the diff from r1 to r3 includes the diff from r1 to r2 and the diff from r2 to r3, since the revision r3 is based on those two diffs.

This is something we can improve in the UI however, as this has caused a good bit of confusion to some users. For example, greying out the revisions corresponding to an intermediate diff would help identifying which pair of revisions are being "diff" at the moment.

Any other suggestions on how to improve this are welcome.
fields.summary: Improve Diff functionality in Crucible and FishEye

fields.description:
To conform with the limit of other Atlassian applications, on Studio.
The length now is only 80 characters what is a lot less than the 150 accepted by JIRA/Confluence/Bamboo.

After CRUC-3863 was implemented the limit of 80 chars started to be enforced and that will generate an error on Studio if the users tries to create a project name that is larger than 80 chars, this used to work because we were using HSQLDB as the underlying database for Crucible on Studio with the 'sql.enforce_strict_size' set to *false*.
fields.summary: Increase the Project name to at least 150 characters

fields.description:
If I go to Crucible on Studio, the log-in page doesn't redirect me back to the review after I log in.

See attached screenshot for the URL and login page. (Also, the login page isn't styled correctly.)

If this is a Studio issue, please let me know and I'll copy it over to JST.
fields.summary: Not permitted page redirects to dashboard after login, not original destination

fields.description:
After reviewing the documentation at http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Creating+a+Snippet+Review, I fully expected to see a Tools menu on the Snippet Review screen. But it is not there (see screen shots).  Tried it both in Chrome 10.0.648.134 and IE 8.0.7600.16385. 

I'm guessing this is a bug as there is no way to close or delete a Snippet review while viewing it.
fields.summary: No Tools Menu on Snippet Review screen

fields.description:
users-v1 could provide more useful data (in order of priority):

* committers mapped to a particular user (not just the reverse lookup from committer to user, as currently provided by {{GET /rest-service/users-v1/\{repository-name\}/\{committer-name\})}}
* email addresses
* an end-point that returns data similar to {{GET /rest-service/users-v1}}, but scoped to a single user
fields.summary: users-v1 REST resource should return mapped committers and other data

There is no error message in the UI or no email notification if backups fail.

However, the logs does record the failure.

It would be nice if we sent out users notification when the backups fail as the users can end up with corrupted backups.

fields.description:
1. Do we need to do an audit of other REST methods that might also suffer from this late computation problem? 

2. Would not a better fix in this case be to move the session close() boundary so that the session exists when the list is being iterated during marshalling? This presumably has the advantage of not loading every beastie in memory at once. For large instances, a full project list might be an expensive thing memory-wise? maybe not, but if other REST methods that return lists of bigger magnitude suffer similarly, this solution may not scale. 

3. Sure the "anonymous user" thing here is a red herring? 

4. Why wasn't this picked up by our tests? Can we enhance our tests such to assert correctness now?

fields.description:
Premise: three different users involved. Let's call them _User 1_, _User 2_ and _User 3_.

_User 1_ creates a review, and assigns _User 2_ as moderator and _User 3_ as reviewer, and starts the review.
At this time, the review is displayed in _User 1_ (author)'s and _User 2_ (moderator)'s dashboard on _Outbox > Out For Review_, and in _User 3_ (reviewer)'s dashboard on _Inbox > To Review_.

When _User 3_ (reviewer) completes the review, it gets moved to _Outbox > Completed_ for him, and for _User 2_ (moderator) it gets moved to _Inbox > To Summarize_, *but for _User 1_ (author) the review is displayed nowhere under My Reviews*. It disappears from the author's dashboard.

However, when _User 2_ (moderator) summarizes and closes the review, it is displayed in his and in the _User 1_ (author)'s dashboard under _Archive > Closed_.

The review should be displayed somewhere in the author's dashboard when reviewers complete the review and it's waiting the moderator to summarize and close it.

Please let me know if you need further explanation.

Kind regards,
Felipe Kraemer
Atlassian Support
